context: [23] The Dyson orbitals for n-butane reveal that the 22Ag excited state has the fewest nodal planes; hence, this state experiences the least suppression, rendering it the dominant SFI channel as seen in Fig. 3A.  [1] (A) TDSE calculations of half-cycle ionization yields for producing the lowest few ionic states for the dominant conformers of 1,3-butadiene (left) and n-butane (right).  [2] The intensity was set to 1.5 Ã— 1013 W/cm2 at a wavelength of 800 nm.  [3] For 1,3-butadiene, ground-state ionization is strongly favored, whereas for n-butane excited-state ionization is more probable.  [4] For more details, see the SOM.  [5] (B) TDSE calculations of half-cycle ionization yields for n-butane into the 2Ag ionic ground state and the strongest coupled ionic excited state (2Bu), shown both with (purple) and without (blue) laser-driven nonresonant interchannel dipole coupling (also known as NME) between the ionic states, for a higher intensity of 1.5 Ã— 1014 W/cm2 at a wavelength of 800 nm.  [6] Channel-resolved ionization yields for two molecular frame field directions, x and y, are presented in the middle and right panels, respectively.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, buta-1,3-diene is analyzed in relation to ionization processes, specifically focusing on its ground-state ionization compared to n-butane. The study highlights that ground-state ionization is strongly favored for buta-1,3-diene, while excited-state ionization is more probable for n-butane. This indicates a significant relationship between the molecular structure of buta-1,3-diene and its ionization behavior under specific conditions.
